an7.68:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an7.68:1.1.eng: “A mendicant with seven qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an7.68:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaparoparaññū ca.
an7.68:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, has self-knowledge, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows individuals high and low.

an7.68:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant one who knows the teachings?

an7.68:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows the teachings:

an7.68:2.3.pli: suttaṃ geyyaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ gāthaṃ udānaṃ itivuttakaṃ jātakaṃ abbhutadhammaṃ vedallaṃ.
an7.68:2.3.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an7.68:2.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ jāneyya—
an7.68:2.4.eng: If a mendicant did not know these teachings,

an7.68:2.5.pli: suttaṃ geyyaṃ …pe… abbhutadhammaṃ vedallaṃ, nayidha ‘dhammaññū’ti vucceyya.
an7.68:2.5.eng: they would not be called ‘one who knows the teachings’.

an7.68:2.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṃ jānāti—
an7.68:2.6.eng: But because they do know these teachings,

an7.68:2.7.pli: suttaṃ geyyaṃ …pe… abbhutadhammaṃ vedallaṃ, tasmā ‘dhammaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:2.7.eng: they are called ‘one who knows the teachings’.

an7.68:2.8.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings.

an7.68:3.1.eng: And how are they one who knows the meaning?

an7.68:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tassa tasseva bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti:
an7.68:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows the meaning of this or that statement:

an7.68:3.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho, ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’ti.
an7.68:3.3.eng: ‘This is what that statement means; that is what this statement means.’

an7.68:3.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tassa tasseva bhāsitassa atthaṃ jāneyya:
an7.68:3.4.eng: If a mendicant did not know the meaning of this or that statement,

an7.68:3.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho, ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’ti, nayidha ‘atthaññū’ti vucceyya.
an7.68:3.5.eng: they would not be called ‘one who knows the meaning’.

an7.68:3.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tassa tasseva bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti:
an7.68:3.6.eng: But because they do know the meaning of this or that statement,

an7.68:3.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho, ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’ti, tasmā ‘atthaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:3.7.eng: they are called ‘one who knows the meaning’.

an7.68:3.8.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings and the one who knows the meaning.

an7.68:4.1.eng: And how are they one who has self-knowledge?

an7.68:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has self-knowledge:

an7.68:4.3.pli: ‘ettakomhi saddhāya sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya paṭibhānenā’ti.
an7.68:4.3.eng: ‘This is the extent of my faith, ethics, learning, generosity, wisdom, and eloquence.’

an7.68:4.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attānaṃ jāneyya:
an7.68:4.4.eng: If a mendicant did not have self-knowledge,

an7.68:4.5.pli: ‘ettakomhi saddhāya sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya paṭibhānenā’ti, nayidha ‘attaññū’ti vucceyya.
an7.68:4.5.eng: they would not be called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.

an7.68:4.6.pli: Yasmā ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attānaṃ jānāti:
an7.68:4.6.eng: But because they do have self-knowledge,

an7.68:4.7.pli: ‘ettakomhi saddhāya sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya paṭibhānenā’ti, tasmā ‘attaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:4.7.eng: they are called ‘one who has self-knowledge’.

an7.68:4.8.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, and the one who has self-knowledge.

an7.68:5.1.eng: And how are they one who knows moderation?

an7.68:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mattaṃ jānāti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ paṭiggahaṇāya.
an7.68:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows moderation when receiving robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an7.68:5.3.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mattaṃ jāneyya cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ paṭiggahaṇāya, nayidha ‘mattaññū’ti vucceyya.
an7.68:5.3.eng: If a mendicant did not know moderation, they would not be called ‘one who knows moderation’.

an7.68:5.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mattaṃ jānāti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ paṭiggahaṇāya, tasmā ‘mattaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:5.4.eng: But because they do know moderation, they are called ‘one who knows moderation’.

an7.68:5.5.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, and the one who knows moderation.

an7.68:6.1.eng: And how are they one who knows the right time?

an7.68:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows the right time:

an7.68:6.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kālo uddesassa, ayaṃ kālo paripucchāya, ayaṃ kālo yogassa, ayaṃ kālo paṭisallānassā’ti.
an7.68:6.3.eng: ‘This is the time for recitation; this is the time for questioning; this is the time for meditation; this is the time for retreat.’

an7.68:6.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālaṃ jāneyya:
an7.68:6.4.eng: If a mendicant did not know the right time,

an7.68:6.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kālo uddesassa, ayaṃ kālo paripucchāya, ayaṃ kālo yogassa, ayaṃ kālo paṭisallānassā’ti, nayidha ‘kālaññū’ti vucceyya.
an7.68:6.5.eng: they would not be called ‘one who knows the right time’.

an7.68:6.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālaṃ jānāti:
an7.68:6.6.eng: But because they do know the right time,

an7.68:6.7.pli: ‘ayaṃ kālo uddesassa, ayaṃ kālo paripucchāya, ayaṃ kālo yogassa, ayaṃ kālo paṭisallānassā’ti, tasmā ‘kālaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:6.7.eng: they are called ‘one who knows the right time’.

an7.68:6.8.pli: Iti dhammaññū, atthaññū, attaññū, mattaññū, kālaññū.
an7.68:6.8.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, the one who knows moderation, and the one who knows the right time.

an7.68:7.1.eng: And how are they one who knows assemblies?

an7.68:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant knows assemblies:

an7.68:7.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ khattiyaparisā, ayaṃ brāhmaṇaparisā, ayaṃ gahapatiparisā, ayaṃ samaṇaparisā.
an7.68:7.3.eng: ‘This is an assembly of aristocrats, of brahmins, of householders, or of ascetics.

an7.68:7.4.pli: Tattha evaṃ upasaṅkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ ṭhātabbaṃ, evaṃ kattabbaṃ, evaṃ nisīditabbaṃ, evaṃ bhāsitabbaṃ, evaṃ tuṇhī bhavitabban’ti.
an7.68:7.4.eng: This one should be approached in this way. This is how to stand, to act, to sit, to speak, or to stay silent when there.’

an7.68:7.5.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parisaṃ jāneyya:
an7.68:7.5.eng: If a mendicant did not know assemblies,

an7.68:7.7.eng: they would not be called ‘one who knows assemblies’.

an7.68:7.8.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parisaṃ jānāti:
an7.68:7.8.eng: But because they do know assemblies,

an7.68:7.9.pli: ‘ayaṃ khattiyaparisā, ayaṃ brāhmaṇaparisā, ayaṃ gahapatiparisā, ayaṃ samaṇaparisā.

an7.68:7.10.pli: Tattha evaṃ upasaṅkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ ṭhātabbaṃ, evaṃ kattabbaṃ, evaṃ nisīditabbaṃ, evaṃ bhāsitabbaṃ, evaṃ tuṇhī bhavitabban’ti, tasmā ‘parisaññū’ti vuccati.
an7.68:7.10.eng: they are called ‘one who knows assemblies’.

an7.68:7.11.pli: Iti dhammaññū, atthaññū, attaññū, mattaññū, kālaññū, parisaññū.
an7.68:7.11.eng: Such is the one who knows the teachings, the one who knows the meaning, the one who has self-knowledge, the one who knows moderation, the one who knows the right time, and the one who knows assemblies.

an7.68:8.1.eng: And how are they one who knows individuals high and low?

an7.68:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dvayena puggalā viditā honti.
an7.68:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands individuals in terms of pairs.

an7.68:8.4.pli: eko ariyānaṃ dassanakāmo, eko ariyānaṃ na dassanakāmo.
an7.68:8.4.eng: one likes to see the noble ones, one does not.

an7.68:8.5.eng: The individual who doesn’t like to see the noble ones

an7.68:8.7.eng: The individual who does like to see the noble ones

an7.68:9.1.eng: Two individuals like to see the noble ones:

an7.68:9.2.pli: eko saddhammaṃ sotukāmo, eko saddhammaṃ na sotukāmo.
an7.68:9.2.eng: one likes to hear the true teaching, one does not.

an7.68:9.3.eng: The individual who doesn’t like to hear the true teaching

an7.68:9.5.eng: The individual who does like to hear the true teaching

an7.68:10.1.eng: Two individuals like to hear the true teaching:

an7.68:10.2.pli: eko ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti, eko anohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti.
an7.68:10.2.eng: one actively listens to the teaching, one does not.

an7.68:10.3.eng: The individual who doesn’t actively listen to the teaching

an7.68:10.5.eng: The individual who does actively listen to the teaching

an7.68:11.1.eng: Two individuals actively listen to the teaching:

an7.68:11.2.pli: eko sutvā dhammaṃ dhāreti, eko sutvā dhammaṃ na dhāreti.
an7.68:11.2.eng: one remembers the teaching they’ve heard, one does not.

an7.68:11.3.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo sutvā na dhammaṃ dhāreti,
an7.68:11.3.eng: The individual who doesn’t remember the teaching they’ve heard

an7.68:11.5.eng: The individual who does remember the teaching they’ve heard

an7.68:12.1.eng: Two individuals remember the teaching they’ve heard:

an7.68:12.2.pli: eko dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, eko dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ na upaparikkhati.
an7.68:12.2.eng: one examines the meaning of the teachings they have remembered, one does not.

an7.68:12.3.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ na upaparikkhati,
an7.68:12.3.eng: The individual who does not examine the meaning of the teachings they have remembered

an7.68:12.5.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati,
an7.68:12.5.eng: The individual who does examine the meaning of the teachings they have remembered

an7.68:13.1.pli: Dve puggalā dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhanti—
an7.68:13.1.eng: Two individuals examine the meaning of the teachings they have remembered:

an7.68:13.2.pli: eko atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno, eko atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya na dhammānudhammappaṭipanno.
an7.68:13.2.eng: one understands the meaning and the teaching and practicesin line with the teaching, one understands the meaning and the teaching but does not practice in line with the teaching.

an7.68:13.3.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya na dhammānudhammappaṭipanno,
an7.68:13.3.eng: The individual who understands the meaning and the teaching but does not practice in line with the principle of the teaching

an7.68:13.5.eng: The individual who understands the meaning and the teaching and practices in line with the principle of the teaching

an7.68:14.1.eng: Two individuals understand the meaning and the teaching and practice in line with the teaching:

an7.68:14.2.pli: eko attahitāya paṭipanno no parahitāya, eko attahitāya ca paṭipanno parahitāya ca.
an7.68:14.2.eng: one practices to benefit themselves but not others, and one practices to benefit both themselves and others.

an7.68:14.3.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo attahitāya paṭipanno no parahitāya,
an7.68:14.3.eng: The individual who practices to benefit themselves but not others

an7.68:14.5.pli: Yvāyaṃ puggalo attahitāya ca paṭipanno parahitāya ca,
an7.68:14.5.eng: The individual who practices to benefit both themselves and others

an7.68:15.1.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dvayena puggalā viditā honti.
an7.68:15.1.eng: That’s how a mendicant understands individuals in terms of pairs.

an7.68:16.1.eng: That’s how a mendicant is one who knows individuals high and low.

an7.68:16.2.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an7.68:16.2.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an7.69:1.1.pli: “Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro paṇḍupalāso hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree belonging to the gods of the thirty-three turn brown, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:1.2.pli: ‘paṇḍupalāso dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni pannapalāso bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:1.2.eng: ‘Now the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree have turned brown! It won’t be long until they fall.’

an7.69:2.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro pannapalāso hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:2.1.eng: When the leaves have fallen, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:2.2.pli: ‘pannapalāso dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni jālakajāto bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:2.2.eng: ‘Now the leaves on the Shady Orchid Tree have fallen. It won’t be long until its foliage starts to regrow.’

an7.69:3.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro jālakajāto hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:3.1.eng: When the foliage starts to regrow, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:3.2.pli: ‘jālakajāto dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni khārakajāto bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:3.2.eng: ‘Now the foliage of the Shady Orchid Tree has started to regrow. It won’t be long until it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately.’

an7.69:4.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro khārakajāto hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:4.1.eng: When it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:4.2.pli: ‘khārakajāto dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni kuṭumalakajāto bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:4.2.eng: ‘Now the Shady Orchid Tree is ready to grow flowers and leaves separately. It won’t be long until buds start to form.’

an7.69:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro kuṭumalakajāto hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:5.1.eng: When the buds start to form, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:5.2.pli: ‘kuṭumalakajāto dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni korakajāto bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:5.2.eng: ‘Now the buds of the Shady Orchid Tree have started to form. It won’t be long until the buds burst.’

an7.69:6.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro korakajāto hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā tasmiṃ samaye honti:
an7.69:6.1.eng: When the buds have burst, the gods are elated. They think:

an7.69:6.2.pli: ‘korakajāto dāni pāricchattako koviḷāro nacirasseva dāni sabbaphāliphullo bhavissatī’ti.
an7.69:6.2.eng: ‘Now the buds of the Shady Orchid Tree have burst. It won’t be long until it fully blossoms.’

an7.69:7.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro sabbaphāliphullo hoti, attamanā, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā pāricchattakassa koviḷārassa mūle dibbe cattāro māse pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārenti. Sabbaphāliphullassa kho pana, bhikkhave, pāricchattakassa koviḷārassa samantā paññāsayojanāni ābhāya phuṭaṃ hoti, anuvātaṃ yojanasataṃ gandho gacchati,
an7.69:7.1.eng: When the Shady Orchid Tree of the gods of the thirty-three has fully blossomed, the gods are elated. For four heavenly months they amused themselves at the root of the tree, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. When the Shady Orchid Tree has fully blossomed, its radiance spreads for fifty leagues, while its fragrance wafts for a hundred leagues.

an7.69:7.2.eng: Such is the majesty of the Shady Orchid Tree.

an7.69:8.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ samaye ariyasāvako agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya ceteti, paṇḍupalāso, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:8.1.eng: In the same way, when a noble disciple plans to go forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its leaves turn brown.

an7.69:9.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, pannapalāso, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:9.1.eng: When a noble disciple shaves off their hair and beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its leaves fall.

an7.69:10.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an7.69:10.1.eng: When a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected,

an7.69:10.2.pli: jālakajāto, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:10.2.eng: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its foliage starts to regrow.

an7.69:11.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an7.69:11.1.eng: When, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a noble disciple enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected,

an7.69:11.2.pli: khārakajāto, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:11.2.eng: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when it’s ready to grow flowers and leaves separately.

an7.69:12.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an7.69:12.1.eng: When, with the fading away of rapture, a noble disciple enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’,

an7.69:12.2.pli: kuṭumalakajāto, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:12.2.eng: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its buds start to form.

an7.69:13.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati,
an7.69:13.1.eng: When, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a noble disciple enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness,

an7.69:13.2.pli: korakajāto, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:13.2.eng: they’re like the Shady Orchid Tree when its buds burst.

an7.69:14.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati,
an7.69:14.1.eng: When a noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements,

an7.69:14.2.pli: sabbaphāliphullo, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako tasmiṃ samaye hoti devānaṃva tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāricchattako koviḷāro.
an7.69:14.2.eng: they’re like the Shady Orchid tree when it fully blossoms.

an7.69:15.1.pli: Tasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye bhummā devā saddamanussāventi:
an7.69:15.1.eng: At that time the earth gods raise the cry:

an7.69:15.2.pli: ‘eso itthannāmo āyasmā itthannāmassa āyasmato saddhivihāriko amukamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an7.69:15.2.eng: ‘This venerable named so-and-so, from such-and-such village or town, the protégé of the venerable named so-and-so, went forth from the lay life to homelessness. They’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an7.69:16.1.pli: Bhummānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā cātumahārājikā devā …pe…
an7.69:16.1.eng: Hearing the cry of the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings …

an7.69:16.5.eng: the gods who love to create …

an7.69:16.6.eng: the gods who control what is created by others …

an7.69:16.7.eng: the gods of the Divinity’s host raise the cry:

an7.69:16.8.pli: ‘eso itthannāmo āyasmā itthannāmassa āyasmato saddhivihāriko amukamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an7.69:16.8.eng: ‘This venerable named so-and-so, from such-and-such village or town, the protégé of the venerable named so-and-so, went forth from the lay life to homelessness. They’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an7.69:16.9.pli: Itiha tena khaṇena tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchati,
an7.69:16.9.eng: And so at that moment, that hour, the cry soars up to the realm of divinity.

an7.69:16.10.eng: Such is the majesty of a mendicant who has ended the defilements.”

an7.7:1.1.pli: Atha kho uggo rājamahāmatto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggo rājamahāmatto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.7:1.1.eng: Then Ugga the government chief minister went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an7.7:2.2.pli: Yāva aḍḍho cāyaṃ, bhante, migāro rohaṇeyyo yāva mahaddhano yāva mahābhogo”ti.
an7.7:2.2.eng: Migāra of Rohaṇa is so rich, so very wealthy.”

an7.7:2.3.pli: “Kīva aḍḍho panugga, migāro rohaṇeyyo, kīva mahaddhano, kīva mahābhogo”ti?

an7.7:2.4.pli: “Sataṃ, bhante, satasahassānaṃ hiraññassa, ko pana vādo rūpiyassā”ti.
an7.7:2.4.eng: “He has a hundred thousand gold coins, not to mention the silver coins!”

an7.7:2.5.pli: “Atthi kho etaṃ, ugga, dhanaṃ netaṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmīti.
an7.7:2.5.eng: “Well, Ugga, that is wealth, I can’t deny it.

an7.7:2.6.pli: Tañca kho etaṃ, ugga, dhanaṃ sādhāraṇaṃ agginā udakena rājūhi corehi appiyehi dāyādehi.
an7.7:2.6.eng: But fire, water, rulers, thieves, and unloved heirs all take a share of that wealth.

an7.7:2.7.pli: Satta kho imāni, ugga, dhanāni asādhāraṇāni agginā udakena rājūhi corehi appiyehi dāyādehi.
an7.7:2.7.eng: There are these seven kinds of wealth that they can’t take a share of.

an7.7:2.9.pli: Saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ, hirīdhanaṃ, ottappadhanaṃ, sutadhanaṃ, cāgadhanaṃ, paññādhanaṃ.
an7.7:2.9.eng: The wealth of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an7.7:2.10.pli: Imāni kho, ugga, satta dhanāni asādhāraṇāni agginā udakena rājūhi corehi appiyehi dāyādehīti.
an7.7:2.10.eng: There are these seven kinds of wealth that fire, water, rulers, thieves, and unloved heirs can’t take a share of.

an7.7:3.1.eng: Faith and ethical conduct are kinds of wealth,

an7.7:3.4.eng: and wisdom is the seventh kind of wealth.

an7.7:4.3.eng: they’re really rich in the world,

an7.7:5.1.eng: So let the wise devote themselves

an7.7:5.3.eng: confidence, and insight into the teaching,

an7.7:5.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”
